story.text: Time seems really straightforward and turns out not to be.

Transported image. [https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/supervillain_plan.png source]

Original comic. [https://xkcd.com/1883 source]
"Daylight savings time is an oxymoron in every programming language ever." [https://twitter.com/dobbse/status/315175658588340227 tweet]
See many different ways to model time (though not timezones) in Eric Evans' [[Exploring Time]]
For a geometric model for thinking about time zones, see [https://apparatus.wiki.dbbs.co?load=saves/TickTock.json TickTock.json]

Constructing that Apparatus model was its own reminder of how many ways there are to screw up time representations.  One must get the order exactly correct when computing local time from UTC and the timezone offset.  One must get the integer sign correct when translating time units into radians for the positions of hands on a clock.  Getting the relations correct between the position of the sun and the positions of our observer or UTC can also be painfully inverted.
UTC is enough for everyone, right? [https://zachholman.com/talk/utc-is-enough-for-everyone-right blog]

Universal Dial Plate 1854. Time zones used to be even more difficult. [https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Universal_Dial_Plate_or_Times_of_all_Nations%2C_1854.jpg/757px-Universal_Dial_Plate_or_Times_of_all_Nations%2C_1854.jpg source]

> So you’ve got a bunch of scientist types around 1960 who are like, hey, time is all screwy we should totes make a standard. And some of them spoke English, and some of them spoke French, which, of course, is the cause of so much conflict over so many generations. (In hindsight, maybe we should have split all those troublemakers up from the start.)
> 
> The English-speaking folk were like yo, this definitely sounds like Coordinated Universal Time, boom, ship it. And the French speakers were like yeah that makes total sense! Temps Universel Coordonné DOES work out well in our language, too, ship it! Then they both looked up and realized cool, they’ve created both CUT and TUC for acronyms. Shit.
> 
> When your standard — that is expressly meant to standardize time — doesn’t even standardize on a standard acronym, well, damn, that probably doesn’t bode well for your standard.
> 
> Or, actually, now that I think about it, this might be the most perfect metaphor about time itself ever created. Maybe we should give them some credit for that. Time never makes sense.
> 
> Anyway, the compromise that arose was that if everyone is special, no one is special, so they created an entirely new set of letters that has no direct relation to any real words for the compromise: UTC.

These posts reminded me that Jon Udell wrote A Literary Appreciation of the Olson Database (of timezones): [https://blog.jonudell.net/2009/10/23/a-literary-appreciation-of-the-olsonzoneinfotz-database/ blog]
A comment in Udell's blog points to Mark Crispin's calendar work for the University of Washington IMAP server: [http://www.washington.edu/imap/documentation/calendar.txt.html doc]
Springs and Neaps: [https://web.archive.org/web/20150906095426/http://use.perl.org/use.perl.org/_godoy/journal/9361.html wayback of use Perl;]

VIEWER //apparatus.wiki.dbbs.co/
DOC saves/TickTock.json
X -4 4
Y -4 4

DOC saves/TickTock.json
X -4 4
Y -4 4
//apparatus.wiki.dbbs.co/?load=saves/TickTock.json&fullScreen=1&viewOnly=1&editLink=1&regionOfInterest={"x":[-4,4],"y":[-4,4]}

//apparatus.wiki.dbbs.co/?load=saves/TickTock.json&fullScreen=1&viewOnly=1&editLink=1&regionOfInterest={"x":[-4,4],"y":[-4,4]}
HEIGHT 200

HEIGHT 300
